questions.title: Does {{respondent.trad_as}} use a fixed broadband connection to the internet, for example DSL, (ADSL, SDSL, VDSL), fibre optic technology, cable technology?

content.title: DSL (Digital Subscriber Line)
content.description: A family of technologies that provides digital data transmission over the wires of a local telephone network. Both telephone and computer can be used at the same time using DSL.

content.title: ADSL (Asymmetric Digital Subscriber Line)
content.description: A type of Digital Subscriber Line (DSL) internet service commonly used in homes. The ‘A’ in ADSL refers to the unequal distribution network bandwidth between downloads and uploads with more bandwidth for download than uploads.

content.title: Mbps (Megabits per second)

blocks.title: Use of cloud computing services
blocks.description:
You have completed the previous section.

This section covers the use of cloud computing.

Cloud computing
ICT services that are used over the internet to access software, computing power, storage capacity, etc.
Cloud computing services must have all of the following characteristics:

  • Are delivered from servers of service providers
  • Can be easily scaled up or down (for example; the number of users or change of storage capacity)
  • Can be used on-demand by the user, at least after the initial set up (without human interaction with the service provider)
  • Are paid for, either by the user, by the capacity used or they are pre-paid
Cloud computing may include connections via Virtual Private Networks (VPN)

This is using cloud computing for running the business’ software applications. This may be provided either as Software as a service (SaaS) or as Infrastructure (hardware/software)  as a Service (IaaS). For the former the business uses the software application that has been developed and it is accessible and used through a browser. For the latter the business maintains control of the software environment.

blocks.title: Invoicing
blocks.description:
You have completed the previous section.

This section covers invoicing completed by your business.

questions.title: In 2017, did {{respondent.trad_as}} issue/send invoices in electronic form, in a standard structure suitable for automated processing, for example EDI, UBL, XML?

content.title: Invoices
content.description: There are invoices in paper form and electronic form. Invoices in electronic form are of two types:

E-invoices in a standard structure suitable for automated processing (for example EDI, UBL, XML), excluding the transmission of PDF files. They are exchanged either directly or via service operators or via an electronic banking system.
Invoices in electronic form not suitable for automated processing, for example e-mails, pdf e-mail attachments, images in TIF, JPEG or other format.

content.title: EDI (Electronic Data Interchange)
content.description: A set of standards for structuring information that is to be electronically exchanged between businesses or organisations. The standards describe formats that emulate documents, eg purchase orders or invoices; define messages and their contents, but not the method of exchanging the messages themselves. An example of EDI is EDIFACT (Electronic Data Interchange for Administration Commerce and Transport standards).

content.title: UBL (Universal Business Language)
content.description: A library of standard electronic XML business documents such as purchase orders and invoices. UBL is designed to plug directly into existing business, legal, auditing, and records management practices. It is designed to eliminate the re-keying of data in existing fax- and paper-based business correspondence and provide an entry point into electronic commerce for small and medium-sized businesses.

content.title: XML (Extensible Markup Language)
content.description: A markup language (mechanism to identify structures) for documents containing structured information. Structured information contains both content (words, pictures, etc.)  and some indication of what role that content plays (for example, content in a section heading has a different meaning from content in a footnote, which means something different to content in a figure caption or content in a database table, etc.).

guidance.show_guidance: Show Invoices, EDI, UBL and XML Definitions
guidance.hide_guidance: Hide Invoices, EDI, UBL and XML Definitions

list: Invoices sent by intermediaries, e.g. accountants, e-invoice service providers, etc.
content.title: Include:

questions.title: In 2017, did {{respondent.trad_as}} issue/send invoices in electronic form not suitable for automated processing, for example, emails, PDF email attachments, images in TIF, JPEG or other formats?

content.title: Invoices
content.description: There are invoices in paper form and electronic form. Invoices in electronic form are of two types:

E-invoices in a standard structure suitable for automated processing (for example EDI, UBL, XML), excluding the transmission of PDF files. They are exchanged either directly or via service operators or via an electronic banking system.
Invoices in electronic form not suitable for automated processing, for example e-mails, pdf e-mail attachments, images in TIF, JPEG or other format.

list: Invoices sent by intermediaries, e.g. accountants, e-invoice service providers, etc.

blocks.title: e-Commerce
blocks.description:
You have completed the previous section.

This section covers E-Commerce.

E-Commerce is the sale or purchase of goods or services conducted over computer networks by methods specifically designed for the purpose of receiving or placing of orders.
The payment and the delivery of the goods or services do not have to be conducted online.
E-Commerce transactions exclude orders made by manually typed emails.

questions.title: During 2017, did {{respondent.trad_as}} receive any orders from customers for goods or services via a website or ‘app’?

content.title: EDI (Electronic Data Interchange)
content.description: A set of standards for structuring information that is to be electronically exchanged between businesses or organisations. The standards describe formats that emulate documents, eg purchase orders or invoices; define messages and their contents, but not the method of exchanging the messages themselves. An example of EDI is EDIFACT (Electronic Data Interchange for Administration Commerce and Transport standards).

content.title: Extranet
content.description: A private network, with restricted access, which uses Internet Protocol for sharing information with customers, suppliers, and other business pertners. It can take the form of a secure extension to an intranet or secure access part of a website. It is usually used for placing orders or accessing information.

list: orders received for utilities, goods, materials and services via an online store, web forms on a website or extranet or ‘app’

answers.description: For example Booking, eBay, Amazon, Amazon Business, Alibaba, Rakuten, Etsy etc

questions.title: During 2017, did {{respondent.trad_as}} receive any orders from customers for goods or services via EDI type messages?

content.title: EDI (Electronic Data Interchange)
content.description: A set of standards for structuring information that is to be electronically exchanged between businesses or organisations. The standards describe formats that emulate documents, eg purchase orders or invoices; define messages and their contents, but not the method of exchanging the messages themselves. An example of EDI is EDIFACT (Electronic Data Interchange for Administration Commerce and Transport standards).

content.title: XML (Extensible Markup Language)
content.description: A flexible way to create common information formats and share both the format and the data on the World Wide Web, intranets and elsewhere.

list: orders received for utilities, goods, materials and services using internet and non-internet EDI, XML, EDIFACT, and automated telephone entry
